Author: jl777c#5810
Content: kept tweaking it to minimize things going offtrack, key changes are to put the exponential after the RST so it makes the harder diff easier, otherwise it was starting from the unmodified diff and easy blocks were spewing out

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the other change i just made was to make it so exp() only triggers based on tipdiff. the exponential side is so fast to adjust with it looking at recent 12, and it inteferes with the RST

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i also use min(origtarget, RST) value as there were cases where the RST value was higher than the original target

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: another strange thing that is making things act weird is that the target from the RST gets gradually easier as tipdiff increases, which is as expected, but then every so often it gets much harder. i cant see how that is possible, so it seems a bug.

Content: oh, i also multiply the ct[] values by 2, 3, 4 depending on how long it took to solve. trying to approximate the effective diff during the block

Author: zawy#5864
Content:
You've mentioned a lot of things very clearly so I can respond to them:  
1) exp() was supposed to be last.   
2) Yes, I figured the exp() would need adjusting like you said.  Remember I suggested 2xT for each of the pruior 12 instead of 1xT if it became a problem.   
3) I would like to RST data before you did the min() inside the loop.  My comments there indicate I was expcting it to be a small problem but I wanted some form of not using min() to prevent it from accidentally going into the exp().   
4) The bug of gettnig much harder is expected if your miners are doing point 5) which is finding hard blocks strangely quickly.  The Poisson has has that kind of distribution and this may be a fundamental bug in RST.  I am thinking about how to merge everything into a single equation.  

Changing exp() is fine. But I need to see the RST data with the 2x harder difficulties (1/2 ct[]) stored on the chain before you made changes to it. What block times does that correspond to?    I don't understand what you're doing multiplying that by 2, 3, 4 because that makes it even easier than we had it before where the solvetimes were fast.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am putting into ct[] targets that are 2x, 3x, or 4x harder

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the logic is that for blocks that take a long time, most of the time the miners are trying to solve much harder targets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it takes more than 3 minutes, i see it trying to to 10x harder than what it eventually solves

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so i tried to put an in between value that is harder than what was solved, but trying to get closer to the average that was attempted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this had a beneficial effect. making it easier, made blocks come out very fast

Author: zawy#5864
Content: The avg target they faced is always 2x higher than the target they solved because target linearly increases.  The Poisson may do something to this perspective that messes it up, but I do not see an error in the reasoning.  Without a modelling program, it would take a lot of work to experimentally derive the correct function, if that reasoning is in error.    If RST W=3 is fixed, W=6 and 12 should be fixed.  W=3 problems can't be isolated if the are mixed together. Without the data,  I do not know if where we left it yesterday needs adjusting or not.
